docs.title: About Me
docs.text:
I'm ZhuYifei, a computational chemistry PhD student specializing in machine learning and non-adiabatic dynamics.

"Knowledge should have no barriers."

docs.title: Gibbs Free Energy Calculation for O₂ to H₂O₂ Reaction
docs.text: This wiki provides a concise guide on calculating the Gibbs free energy (ΔG) for the reaction where O₂ is reduced to H₂O₂ via a 2-electron oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) pathway on a catalyst surface (*). The process is key to understanding catalyst efficiency in producing H₂O₂.

docs.title: Reaction Pathway
docs.text:
The ORR pathway involves these steps:

  1. O₂(g) → *O₂: O₂ adsorbs onto the catalyst.
  2. *O₂ + H⁺ + e⁻ → *OOH: Proton-electron transfer forms *OOH.
  3. *OOH + H⁺ + e⁻ → *HOOH: Another transfer forms *HOOH (adsorbed H₂O₂).
  4. *HOOH → H₂O₂(l) + *: H₂O₂ desorbs into liquid phase.

docs.title: General Formula
docs.text:
For each step:

\[ \Delta G = \Delta E + \Delta \text{ZPE} - T \times \Delta S \]
  • ΔE: Electronic energy change (from DFT).
  • ΔZPE: Zero-point energy change.
  • T × ΔS: Entropy contribution (T = 298.15 K).

Proton-electron steps use the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model: \(G(\text{H}^+ + \text{e}^-) = \frac{1}{2} G(\text{H}_2)\) at U = 0 V, pH = 0.

docs.title: Step-by-Step ΔG
docs.text:
1. O₂(g) → *O₂: \(\Delta G_1 = G(*\text{O}_2) - G(*) - G(\text{O}_2\text{(g)})\)
  2. *O₂ + H⁺ + e⁻ → *OOH: \(\Delta G_2 = G(*\text{OOH}) - G(*\text{O}_2) - \frac{1}{2} G(\text{H}_2)\)
  3. *OOH + H⁺ + e⁻ → *HOOH: \(\Delta G_3 = G(*\text{HOOH}) - G(*\text{OOH}) - \frac{1}{2} G(\text{H}_2)\)
  4. *HOOH → H₂O₂(l) + *: \(\Delta G_4 = G(*) + G(\text{H}_2\text{O}_2\text{(l)}) - G(*\text{HOOH})\)

docs.title: \(\Delta G_U\): Electrode Potential
docs.text:
\(\Delta G_U = -n \times e \times U\)

  • \(n\): Number of electrons (1 per proton-electron step).
  • \(U\): Electrode potential (V vs. SHE).

Set \(U = 0\) V for baseline; adjust as needed.

docs.title: \(\Delta G_{\text{pH}}\): pH Effect
docs.text:
\(\Delta G_{\text{pH}} = 0.0592 \times \text{pH} \, \text{(eV)}\)

  • pH = 0 (acidic): \(\Delta G_{\text{pH}} = 0\).
  • Adjust for other pH values (e.g., pH = 7 → 0.414 eV).

docs.title: Entropy (\(S\)) Calculation
docs.text:
If you calculate \(ΔG\) using Gaussian, the \(G\) can be obtained directly. Otherwise, you might need to calculate \(ΔG\) with \(ΔS\).

  • Adsorbed Species: From frequency analysis (e.g., VASP):
  • Vibrational factor: \(x_i = \frac{100 \times c \times h \times \nu_i}{k_B \times T}\).
  • Partition function: \(p f_i = \frac{x_i}{e^{x_i} - 1} - \log(1 - e^{-x_i})\).
  • Total entropy: \(S = \frac{R \times \sum p f_i}{1000 \times 96.485}\) (eV/K).
  • Gas Phase (O₂, H₂, H₂O₂): Use Gaussian 16 (6-311G* basis) to calculate vibrational, rotational, and translational contributions.

docs.title: Free Energy Diagram
docs.text:
• Reference: O₂(g) + * = 0 eV.
  • Plot: *O₂ (ΔG₁), *OOH (ΔG₁ + ΔG₂), *HOOH (ΔG₁ + ΔG₂ + ΔG₃), H₂O₂(l) + * (ΔG₁ + ΔG₂ + ΔG₃ + ΔG₄).

docs.title: Key Points to Note
docs.text:
• O₂(g) Correction: DFT underestimates O₂(g) stability. Use:$$ G(\text{O}_2\text{(g)}) = 2G(\text{H}_2\text{O}) - 2G(\text{H}_2) + 4.92 \, \text{eV} $$
  • H₂O₂(l) Adjustment: Convert $G(\text{H}_2\text{O}_2\text{(g)}) $ to liquid phase: \(G(\text{H}_2\text{O}_2\text{(l)}) = G(\text{H}_2\text{O}_2\text{(g)}) - 0.28 \, \text{eV}\)
  • Adsorption Sites: Optimize *O₂, *OOH, *HOOH configurations for stability.
  • Consistency: Use identical DFT settings for all species.
  • Corrections: Include ZPE, entropy, $ \Delta G_U $, and $ \Delta G_{\text{pH}} $ if needed.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Accurate ΔG calculation for O₂ to H₂O₂ requires precise energy terms, gas-phase corrections, and consistent methods. These steps enable a reliable free energy diagram for evaluating ORR catalysts.

docs.title: 12 Other Algorithms
docs.text:
• Bitwise Operation: 1356

These problems involve specialized data structures like tries, segment trees, binary indexed trees (BIT), or union-find (disjoint set).

**Example:**Search in Rotated Sorted Array, Reverse Bits, Palindrome Number.
